Do you have to have this test??

You don't have to, kupi, but i would venture to say it's dangerous not to.  Gestational diabetes is pretty indiscriminate (even if you're a waif healthnut, you can still get it and it can still cause some pretty scare problems).  Having a huge baby because of increased uncontrolled bloodsugar can be very dangerous.  So this is one of those tests i say definitely do it.  If you know, then you can control the bloodsugar and keep you and baby healthy.  If you don't know, you're taking a big risk with both your health.As far as those asking if it was fasting, just remember that it's not just sugar that elevates bloodsugar.  Any carb will do this.  As any dentist will tell you, there is no difference in drinking a soda or eating a bowl of pasta before bed.  It all breaks down to simple sugars.  Same thing in your digestive tract.  Pasta, bread, etc.  It will elevate your blood sugar.  There is no doubt about it.As much as you want to "just make it by" and not get stuck with a gestational diabetes diagnosis, if you have it, you want to know so that you can minimize the complications associated with it.Eating the night before or that morning shouldn't make much of a difference.  But obviously it can make some difference.  But you don't want to give the test a bizarre circumstance to go off of.  Do you normally starve yourself at night and in the morning?  No.  This is not a test that says whether you've been bad or good, it's a test that determines if your body can handle blood sugar the way it needs to right now and producing the amount of insulin it needs to in order to keep you from some dangerous scenarios.I have the same thoughts, "oh please please please, im going to eat only protein for 12 hrs before the test, etc etc, i don't want to have gestational diabetes, maybe i can just barely pass!" But when it comes down to it, that's a dangerous attitude for me to have.  Diabetes is hard to deal with because you feel fine and don't know something is wrong, but the results of gestational diabetes (or any diabetes) run rampant can be life-threatening for you and your baby.Anyway, just some words of caution----i'm not saying anyone feels the way i do and needs to hear this stuff, but just in case you keep thinking like me and want to "beat the test"... there you go.
